change.item: Revised following reprocessing. Created series and removed misfiled materials belonging to the College of Engineering.

repository.corpname: University of Hartford Archives & Special Collections

did.abstract: The collection consists of records from the Ward College of Technology from 1948 to 2003.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to all researchers.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The materials in this collection may be protected by copyright law (U.S. Code: Title 17). Any use of the material which exceeds fair use requires permission from the copyright holder. Researchers are solely responsible for obtaining the proper permission(s) for their use of the material.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Adapted from the Ward College of Technology Website in 2006:

The Ward School was an early affiliated college of the University of Hartford. The College has had a long and complex history and has been known by many different names. In 2003 the College of Engineering and Ward, by then known as the Ward College of Technology, merged to become the College of Engineering, Technology and Architecture (CETA).. The origins of Ward begin with the vision of Hartford industrialist Samuel I. Ward, president of Crystal Research Laboratories (CRL). During Ward War II, CRL emerged as leading supplier of specialized electronic devices, including piezoelectric crystals. The post-war expansion of the electronics industry created a new opportunity for CRL. Anticipating a growing need for skilled technicians to serve the youthful industry, Mr. Ward formed CRL School of Electronics in 1948. On February 24, 1948, the school opened with a class of 75. The school prospered and soon outgrew its original training session. In 1952, Mr. Ward gave the school to Hillyer College to secure its continued development as an educational institution. At this time, the school was renamed the Ward School of Electronics and moved to 44 Niles Street. In 1957, Hillyer merged with the Hartford Art School and the Hartt School of Music to create the University of Hartford. Ward's academic programs grew apace with the development of the profession and remained at the forefront of engineering technology education. In 1964, it established an associate degree program and became Ward Technical Institute. Fifteen years later, Ward created Connecticut's only baccalaureate-level program in Electronic Engineering Technology. In 1971-72, the Institute became Samuel I. Ward Technical College. In the fall of 1972, the College moved to East Hall on the University's campus. Ward's portfolio was further expanded in 1982 with the addition of an associate degree program in Computer Engineering Technology. The associate and baccalaureate programs in Electronic Engineering Technology are accredited by the Technology Accreditation Commission of the Accreditation Board for Engineering and Technology. Effective September 1, 1986, the University's Board of Regents changed the College's name to Samuel I. Ward College of Technology to better reflect the roles which its graduates play in business and industry, the increasing sophistication of its programs, and the growing professionalism of engineering technology. September 1991 the Ward College of Technology began a baccalaureate degree program in Architectural Engineering Technology as the start of its mission to diversify and increase the number of technologies offered by the College. The Architectural Engineering technology program is also accredited by the Technology Accreditation Commission of the Accreditation Board for Engineering and Technology. In 1992, the College announced the establishment of a baccalaureate program in Mechanical Engineering Technology, to commence in the fall of 1993. In 1995, the College added a baccalaureate program in Audio Engineering Technology and the Computer Engineering Technology Major added a baccalaureate level. Chemical Engineering Technology followed the following year. In 1998 Ward College of Technology celebrated the 50th anniversary of its founding. In 1999 Ward College assumed management of the Connecticut Space Grant Consortium. In 2003 the College of Engineering and the Ward College of Technology merged to become the College of Engineering, Technology and Architecture. Also in 2003 construction of ISET, Integrated Science, Engineering and Technology (ISET) complex began construction. In the fall of 2004 the Master of Architecture program began.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: In 2015, the call number was changed from HW to ARCH072.In 2019, the title of the collection was changed from "Ward School collection" to "Ward College of Technology records."
Earlier processors unknown [likely Ethel Bacon and Margaret Mair]; reprocessed and updated by Prachi Bhandutia, Sep. 2019.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains correspondence, reports, memorandums, printed ephemera, meeting minutes, photographs, and audio-visual recordings from the Ward College of Technology from 1948 until its merger with the College of Engineering in 2003.

The majority of the collection consists of subject files which cover topics ranging from joining Hillyer College, planning facility spaces, accreditation and self-study reports and other documentation pertaining to the operations of the school, to histories written about the school and anniversary celebrations. Faculty meeting minutes from 1985-2003 are also a sizeable portion of the collection.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged in six series: I. Subject Files, II. Ward Faculty Meeting Minutes, III. Photographs, IV. Recordings, V. Artifacts, and VI. Duplicates.

controlaccess.subject: Buildings
controlaccess.corpname: Crystal Research Laboratories.. School of Electronics
Samuel I. Ward College of Technology

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This file consists primarily of correspondence and reports created in preparation for, and as a result of, various accreditations including from the Engineers' Council for Professional Development. Additional information regarding Self-studies can be found in the Self-Study file.
